results.abstract: Representative Gabrielle Giffords returned to the Capitol for the first time since being shot to vote in favor of the debt ceiling compromise.

headline.main: Giffords's Return Marks Moment of Unity in Divided House

results.snippet: Representative Gabrielle Giffords returned to the Capitol for the first time since being shot to vote in favor of the debt ceiling compromise.

byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR, SARAH WHEATON and JEFF ZELENY

results.lead_paragraph: The clock was running down, and the debt ceiling compromise did not yet have enough ayes to pass. Then, slowly, applause started trickling through the House chamber. The clapping grew over the next half minute, until finally, the person who somehow managed to draw universal admiration from the frayed body came into view.

headline.print_headline: For Giffords, House Shows It Can Unite
headline.main: Giffords Returns, as Does Unity, Briefly

results.snippet: Representative Gabrielle Giffords returned to the House for the first time since an assassination attempt in January.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JEFF ZELENY

results.lead_paragraph: Representative Gabrielle Giffords returned to the House for the first time since an assassination attempt in January.

results.abstract: Rep Gabrielle Giffords makes an unexpected appearance in the House chamber to cast one of the last votes needed to pass the measure to raise the nation's debt limit; she is greeted by loud applause from both sides of the aisle, a unifying moment that caps a divisive, partisan battle; it is the first time she has been in the chamber since she was critically injured in an assassination attempt in January in Tucson; photos (M)

headline.main: For Giffords, House Shows It Can Unite

results.snippet: Representative Gabrielle Giffords returned to the House for the first time since an assassination attempt in January.

byline.original: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER and JEFF ZELENY

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- With two minutes to go and roughly 20 votes needed to pass a bill to raise the nation's debt limit, a smattering of applause rippled from a corner of the House chamber. After a few seconds of confusion, a flash of teal jacket could be seen almost floating among a sea of Democrats. There she was, Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona, appearing unexpectedly Monday evening to cast one of the last votes needed to send the measure over the top.

results.abstract: Giffords for Congress campaign organization is in place, but lacks the most crucial element of all for success--an announcement from Rep Gabrielle Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, that she is willing and able to run; aides say that she still has work to do on her recovery and her surprise appearance in Congress did not signal a new public phase to her life; photo (M)

headline.main: Giffords Race Lacks Only the Candidate

results.snippet: Representative Gabrielle Giffords’s staff said Monday’s appearance on the House floor did not signal a new public phase to her life.
results.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX -- A Giffords for Congress campaign organization is in place, with a skeleton staff of strategists and fund-raisers and a sizable bank account. But what the re-election effort lacks is the most crucial element of all for success: an announcement by Representative Gabrielle Giffords that she is willing and able to run. Her surprise decision to fly to Washington this week to vote on the debt ceiling bill remained a closely guarded secret until she walked into the House chambers, and likewise, Ms. Giffords, Democrat of Arizona, is keeping her constituents, and her aides, waiting on her political future.

results.abstract: Anthony Tommasini reviews Santa Fe Opera production of Vivaldi opera Griselda, directed by Peter Sellars and starring Isabel Leonard and David Daniels; photo (M)

headline.main: One Cruel King, By Way of Vivaldi

results.snippet: The Santa Fe Opera is presenting what it is being billed as the first major American production of Vivaldi’s “Griselda.”
results.lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. -- Vivaldi would surely find it frustrating, if not a little strange, that his achievement as a composer today is distorted by the cultlike popularity of ''The Four Seasons.'' He was indeed a master of Baroque instrumental music. Still, from his early days he was powerfully drawn to the theater and to the voice. He wrote nearly 50 operas. Yet productions are rare. The mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli brought overdue attention to Vivaldi's operas with a successful album of arias in 1999 and a subsequent concert tour. Now the Santa Fe Opera is presenting what it is being billed as the first major American production of Vivaldi's ''Griselda,'' a remarkable work first performed in Venice in 1735. It opened here last month. The director is Peter Sellars, whose 1981 staging of Handel's ''Orlando'' at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., set at Cape Canaveral with the knight Orlando portrayed as an astronaut, brought Mr. Sellars and that Handel masterpiece to widespread attention.

results.snippet: A selected guide to events for, by and about children and teenagers in New York.
results.lead_paragraph: 'WHAT'S YOUR FAVORITE SPACE?' On Wednesday scores of children will dress potatoes at the Eventi Hotel in Chelsea. But don't expect butter, sour cream or other condiments. This project isn't gastronomical but astronomical.

headline.main: A Confection of Pop, And Newport Chops

results.snippet: New Music from Frank Ocean, Sam Yahel and Blitzen Trapper.
results.lead_paragraph: Sam Yahel During the final stretch of ''From Sun to Sun'' (Origin), his adept, engaging new album, the keyboardist Sam Yahel offers a glimpse of what might have been. Downhill-skiing through a pair of songbook standards -- ''So in Love'' and ''Taking a Chance on Love,'' linked by an interlude with a classical tinge -- he plays crisply over fast-swinging rhythm, the picture of mainstream post-bop piano excellence.
